Single-atom catalysts (SACs) show potential applications for various organic transformation reactions due to their easy recyclability, high exposure to active sites, and unique electronic structures. Owing to highly exposed active sites, SACs exhibit superior catalytic activity and chemoselectivity compared to metal nanoparticles. This mini-review comprehensively outlines the recent progress in chemoselective hydrogenation, dehydrogenation, CC and CN cross-coupling reactions, peroxymonosulfate activation, production of hydrogen and ammonia by employing 3d transition metals such as Co, Cu, Fe, Ni-based SACs. These reactions are key steps in organic synthetic chemistry and pharmaceutical industries, and utilizing earth-abundant 3d-metal SACs without compromising the selectivity and activity made these reactions cost-effective, sustainable, and industrially applicable. We also illustrate the mechanistic pathways for these reactions and highlight the key challenges and future opportunities to improve the existing SACs. Moreover, we believe that this review may help to address the existing issues of chemoselectivity in organic synthesis as well as promote the development of SACs. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Single atom catalyst 3d transition metal catalyst Organic transformation reactions Cost-effective catalyst Chemoselectivity Data availability No new data was produced because it is a review article. 1 Introduction Conventionally, organic synthetic chemistry serves a significant and vital role in producing thousands of pharmaceutically or medicinally useful compounds or fine chemicals, dyes, pigments, and hydrogen production which greatly enhance the quality of human life [1–6]. Additionally, the removal of contaminants or pharmaceutical drugs from wastewater by transforming them into value-added chemicals through oxidation reaction is an important application of organic transformation[7–9]. Overuse of therapeutic agents, antimicrobial, and antibiotic medicines cause the increase of pharmaceutical waste and contaminants in industrial and hospital wastewater. These contaminants cause severe health issues and affect humans and environment badly [10–12]. Moreover, indoor HCHO has a harmful impact on human health and the environment, it can be removed by oxidation and conversion into CO2 and water [13,14]. In this regard, the removal of these contaminants and pollutants is highly desirable with high selectivity and activity. Additionally, hydrogen is a major source of energy that can be utilized to produce electricity in fuel cells. Compared to fossil fuels, hydrogen has high energy per unit of weight and it can produce electricity that powers industry and automobiles [15–17]. To complement this, catalysts have been explored extensively to improve the atom economy of the reaction, reduce the consumption of energy, and decrease the cost of production [18]. In particular, heterogeneous catalysts getting great attention due to their extraordinary properties like easy recovery, low preparation cost, and high thermal stability [19–21]. Nanoparticles are well-known examples of heterogeneous catalysts. They have high surface area, easy synthesis process, easy recyclability, and recoverability which made them industrially applicable and useful [21,22]. However, they have low exposure to active sites and usually show low reaction selectivity due to their low miscibility or low interaction with the reactant [23]. In this context, more recently single atom catalysts (SACs) are the front runner owing to their properties which allow them to act as a bridge between both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts [24–26]. SACs have each metal atom as an isolated atom over supported material where isolated metal atoms act as active sites of the catalyst [27,28]. SACs have easy recovery, high exposure to active sites, high selectivity towards desired products, and high thermal stability. In SACs, the metal atom is well dispersed over the metal oxide support and acts as an active site for catalytic reactions. This dispersion of metal atoms plays an important role in decreasing the overall process cost of the catalyst without compromising the catalytic performance. In SACs, a very small amount of active metal loading (max. 20 wt%) efficiently improves the catalytic activity and can be utilized as a substitute for high-cost metal catalysts i.e., 4d and 5d metals (Ru, Rh, Pt, Pd, Au, Ag, Ir etc.). [29–32] However, 4d and 5d metals have excellent catalytic activity and selectivity for various organic transformation reactions like hydrogenation, coupling reactions, oxidation reactions, CO2 valorization reactions, etc. [33–35]. but the scarcity of these heavy metals in the Earth's crust makes their extraction and processing difficult and costly due to their limited availability [36,37]. Additionally, the rarity of these metals renders them foreign to most terrestrial organisms, resulting in heightened toxicity and potential environmental harm [38,39]. An emerging area of interest in green chemistry involves developing new catalytic systems based on less toxic and environmentally friendly elements like 3d metals. [40,41] While industrial applications of these metals are limited, they have been utilized by nature for extensive periods, often serving as active centers in metalloenzymes, demonstrating their inherent potential as catalysts [42]. Hence, in this context, the use of 3d metal catalysts are better alternative to make the catalytic process cost-effective and economical. Furthermore, the ability to manipulate specific single-atom catalyst (SAC) structures enables the creation of base metal catalysts that exhibit similar activity levels to noble metal catalysts [43]. Thus, SACs may pave the path of a transformative phase in heterogeneous catalysis, where we can precisely regulate the properties of well-dispersed single-atom active sites to achieve desired catalytic outcomes. Recently, SACs have been explored for various organic transformations such as hydrogenation of nitroarenes, cinnamaldehyde[44,45], semihydrogenation of acetylene[46], hydrogen production from formic acid and ammonia, various oxidation reactions like methane oxidation, partial oxidation of benzene, pollutants degradation via peroxymonosulfate activation, coupling reactions etc. (Fig. 1 ). These organic transformation reactions play a vital role in organic synthesis for synthesizing pharmaceutical drugs, dyes, agrochemicals, etc. The product of chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes is the key intermediate in various synthetic steps (Fig. 2 ) [47–49]. Therefore, SACs show a great potential for such reactions which have been concluded in this review. There are several review articles where electrochemical and photochemical CO2 conversion into methane, methanol, formic acid, etc. using SACs were discussed in detail [50,51]. There are some recent reviews where electrochemical CO2 reduction, OER, HER fuel production, and thermochemical gas-phase reactions using SACs are discussed in detail. [52–55] Song et al. [28] in a review article discussed the hydrogenation and oxygenation reactions of fine chemicals and Fang et al. [26]. discussed the synthesis of SACs with the discussion of their application in heterogeneous catalysis focusing on noble metals. Moreover, in our recent review[56] we have discussed the CO2 hydrogenation to methane using SACs in detail with synthetic processes and mechanisms. Hence, we have narrowed down our discussion and focused on the organic transformation reactions other than CO2 valorization using 3d transition metal-based single-atom catalysts. In this review, all recent reports from 2020 to 2023 are covered using SACs for various organic transformation reactions. 2 Organic transformations using SACs 2.1 Hydrogenation reactions 2.1.1 Chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes In industries, for the chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes, H2 pressure and costly metal catalysts i.e., Pd, Pt, Ru, Rh, etc. have been utilized which increases the overall process cost [19]. Even though, when a non-noble metal catalyst is used, it involves high reaction temperatures, long reaction times, and higher pressures with low selectivity and produces dehalogenated and indiscriminate hydrogenation products under high H2 pressure [57]. High hydrogen pressure hinders the application of catalytic reactions for industrial purposes because storing hydrogen requires extra attention and safe handling. Hydrogen embrittlement poses a significant challenge in such scenarios and warrants careful attention to avoid accidents [58]. Securing safe hydrogen storage systems necessitates the advancement of storage materials and the adaptation of current ones. Moreover, noble metal catalysts have a low abundance and high cost which make these processes extremely expensive and not adaptable for large-scale setups. Hence, single-atom catalysts of 3d transition metals show good catalytic activity and selectivity for such reactions with the tuning of coordination environments around the single metal atom without compromising the selectivity. In this regard, Li et al. [27]. utilized the Co-based SACs for chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes to corresponding anilines in the presence of molecular hydrogen and ethanol: water mixture as solvent at 80 ℃. The Co-H species showed chemoselectivity towards the nitro group over other substituents. The proposed mechanistic pathway includes three major steps: addition of H2 on the cobalt site, cleavage of H2, and reduction of the substrate as shown below in Fig. 3 , where the cleavage of H2 is identified as a rate-determining step. Depending on the circumstances of the reaction, protic-solvent-mediated H-shuttling, and base-assisted deprotonation are the two potential processes, and therefore, heterolysis of H2 between the metal center and the neighbouring coordination sphere occurred. The catalyst was utilized for 20 substrates and in all the cases excellent yield was obtained. Furthermore, Liu et al. [59]. synthesized nitrogen-doped graphene-derived Co SACs where acrylonitrile derived carbon loading method was utilized to prepare Co@Nx-C-800 catalyst (annealing temperature 800 ℃). Mesoporous single-atomic cobalt catalyst with Co-N4 active sites showed excellent catalytic activity for 20 substrates with 1.5 MPa hydrogen gas and ethanol as solvent at 120 ℃ and recyclability up to seven cycles. Based on DFT calculations and EXAFS fitting, they have proposed that Co-N is four-coordinated which acts as a catalytic active center (Fig. 4 ). Moreover, Li et al. [60]. synthesized four types of Co-N-C catalysts as shown in Fig. 5 and utilized them for chemoselective reduction of nitroarene using 3-nitro styrene as model substrate with 10 bar pressure of H2, EtOH: H2O as solvent at 80 ℃ temperature. Co-Phen catalyst (derived from Co-phenanthroline complex with carbon black) showed 80% conversion with 99% selectivity towards amine product. The comparative studies for all four materials were performed by solvent screening, poisoning test, acid-leaching test, etc. which revealed that protic-solvent dependence, antipoisoning, acid resistance, and reversible deactivation are unusual generalities (Fig. 6 ). They further estimated that Co–N x of Co SACs are the main active sites of the Co–N–C catalysts. Moreover, nitrogen-assembled Co SACs (Co-NAC) were synthesized by Lin et al. [61]. with high surface area, high nitrogen content, poison resistance capability, and excellent catalytic activity. The characterization studies confirmed that Co is coordinated on mesoporous nitrogen-assembled carbon (NAC) with four coordination sites. As synthesized catalyst showed high conversion and selectivity with 19.7 h−1 TON for 3-nitrostyrene substrate using MeOH: H2O solvent with 2 MPa hydrogen pressure at 80 ℃. Co-NAC catalyst exhibits excellent promise for ongoing use in the chemical industry by demonstrating resistance to poisons comprising sulfur (20 equivalents) and strong non-oxidizing acid (8 M). Similarly, Song et al. [62]. synthesized a Nitrogen coordinated Zn based SACs via pyrolysis of ZIF-8 (zeolite imidazole framework) at different temperatures and based on temperature they named them as Zn-N-C-1123, Zn-N-C-1223 and Zn-N-C-1273 respectively for 1123 K, 1223 K and 1273 K which have 4,3,2 coordination number. This number indicates the coordination numbers of nitrogen with Zn, i.e., Zn-Nx where x = 2,3,4. Among all catalysts, Zn-N3 in Zn-N-C-1223 showed superior catalytic activity over other catalysts. It was observed that the coordination number of single atomic Zn is affecting the catalytic activity of transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes to arylamine. Moreover, the order of catalytic performance for synthesized SACs was estimated as Zn-N-C-1223 > Zn-N-C-1273 > Zn-N-C-1123. Computational studies revealed that decreasing the coordination number increases the electron density of the Zinc atom and promotes the H-acceptor sites for improved catalytic performance in the hydrogenation reaction. Additionally, Feng et al. [63]. synthesized Ni SACs with 4.9 wt% metal loading over nitrogen-doped hollow carbon spheres (NHCS) from ZIF as a precursor for transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes (Fig. 7 ). They compared the catalytic activity of Ni nanoparticles with the synthesized Ni SACs and observed that the SACs showed high catalytic activity of 29.9 h −1 TOF under mild reaction conditions. DFT calculations revealed that Ni-N3 plays an important role in enhancing the chemo-selectivity of Ni SACs by activating the hydrazine hydrate and nitrobenzene. The rate-determining step for this hydrogenation reaction was found to be the hydrogenation of the -NOH group. Moreover, Zhang et al. [64]. synthesized nitrogen, sulfur dual coordinated Co SACs (Co1/NSC-AT) supported on porous carbon from protein-metal ions aerogel. The catalyst showed excellent performance towards hydrogenation reaction under mild reaction conditions i.e., 35 °C and 1 bar hydrogen pressure. DFT calculations revealed that the N, S-coordinated Co single-atom center Co1S1N3 is an active site with a lower energy barrier than N-coordinated ones (e.g., Co1N4) in the rate-determining step of hydrogenation reaction (Fig. 8 ). The electronic structures of Co single atoms can be tailored in N, S dual-coordinated environments, which helps with H desorption from the active sites and accelerates the hydrogenation process. Additionally, Zhou et al. [65]. explored the effect of coordination environment by varying metals of Fe, Co, and Ni and compared the catalytic activity for hydrogenation reaction. N-coordinated with metal and carbon matrix was synthesized using glutamic acid as the N/C source, ammonia gas as pyrolysis gas, and nanoparticulate silica as a hard template. They have observed that by changing the pyrolysis temperature (700–900 ℃), the doping of N and coordination number (CN) is greatly affected. Also, with ammonia gas, the doping of N is enhanced as compared to the case when N2 was used. Consequently, the capacity of M-N-C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) to activate H2 increases with the decrease in CN, improving catalytic efficiency in the chemoselective hydrogenation process. The increase in electron density of Ni SACs was observed with a decrease in CN of Ni-N which as a result, enhances the dissociation of H2 and high catalytic activity was achieved for chemoselective hydrogenation. When comparing the capability of Co, Ni, and Fe for hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene, SACs of Co-N-C showed the highest TOF of 152.3 h−1 with 99% selectivity. Similarly, Cai et al. [66]. synthesized Co single atom over N-doped hollow porous carbon nanospheres (NHPCN) and utilized that for chemoselective hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. The catalyst was synthesized in several steps where first the synthesis of carboxylated polystyrene nanospheres (PS) was done followed by zeolite framework (ZIF) with Co and Zn was synthesized i.e., PS@ZnCo-ZIF (20:1). This ZIF further pyrolyzed at 920 ℃ which yield the Co SACs named as Co SAs/NHPCN as shown in Fig. 9 . They have obtained excellent selectivity and catalytic performance for various substrates at 110 ℃ temperature with molecular hydrogen. Furthermore, Fe-based SACs were reported recently for chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes using hydrazine hydrate [67–69]. Yun et al. [67]. by pyrolysis of Fe-ZIF under Ar atmosphere obtained catalyst known as FeSAs/Fe2O3A C s/NPC where NPC stands for N-doped polyhedral carbon. When compared with Fe SACs and Fe NPs, synthesized material showed excellent catalytic activity with 1923 h–1 TOF for chemoselective hydrogenation of nitrobenzene owing to the synergistic effect between FeSAs and Fe2O3ACs. DFT studies revealed that to produce hydrogen, iron SACs prefer to decompose hydrazine, while the surface of Fe2O3AC is more active in reducing nitrobenzene to aniline (Fig. 10 ). The catalytic reaction was performed using hydrazine hydrate as a reducing agent with ethanol as solvent at room temperature. Additionally, Lu et al. [68]. reported iron on N-doped carbon (FeSA@NC-20A) SACs via pyrolysis of aniline-modified FeZn-ZIFs without any acid etching procedure, in water at room temperature and utilized it for chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes. They have also explored the reaction pathway for a catalytic reaction where NH activation of hydrazine and reduction of nitroarenes occurs on the FeN4 site which is the key step for the reaction (Fig. 11 ). The catalyst FeSA@NC-20A showed excellent recyclability up to 10 cycles and TON up to 1727 h−1 for a broad substrate scope. Moreover, Cheong et al. [69]. performed chemoselective transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes using hydrazine hydrate with an iron-based mesoporous N-doped catalyst (Fe1/N–C). The synthesized catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity for a broad substrate scope at 60 ℃ temperature with ethanol as solvent. Computational studies revealed that the excellent hydrogenation activity for nitroarenes is attributed to a combination of factors including the lowered energy barrier and the atomic dispersion of partially positively charged Fe atoms. Additionally, Jin et al. [70] explored an atomic Co1/NPC catalyst with unsymmetrical single Co1-N3P1 sites for chemoselective nitrobenzene hydrogenation reaction which showed excellent catalytic performance with 6560 h−1 turnover frequency. DFT calculations revealed that the Co1-N3P1 coordination increases the electron density of the cobalt atom, enhancing its ability to dissociate H2 as shown in Fig. 12 . They have compared the catalytic performance with previous reports which confirmed that obtained TOF is 60 times higher than that of Co1-N4 SACs. Co1/NPC catalyst showed a large substrate scope and >99 % selectivity for various substrates. We have summarized recently published results using SACs for chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes (Table 1 ). 2.1.2 Hydrogenation of 2,3,5-trimethyl benzoquinone (TMBQ) 2,3,5-Trimethylhydroquinone (TMHQ) is a pivotal intermediate in the synthesis of vitamin E [71,72]. Traditionally, TMHQ is obtained via the direct reduction of 2,3,5-trimethylbenzoquinone (TMBQ) using a noncatalytic process, wherein sodium thiosulfate acts as a stoichiometric reducing agent. However, this conventional approach presents several drawbacks, including substantial sewage release, elevated costs associated with the reducing agent, and suboptimal yields of the target product. Consequently, considerable scientific efforts have been dedicated to exploring heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation routes for the conversion of TMBQ to TMHQ, employing molecular hydrogen as a sustainable alternative hydrogen source, particularly suitable for industrial applications. It was reported that the Co-based catalyst showed good catalytic performance for TMHQ production. In this regard, Cai et al. [66] synthesized Co SA/NHPCN using ZIF as a template (Fig. 9 ). They have utilized Co-based SACs for the hydrogenation of TMBQ to TMHQ and observed that atomically dispersed Co single atom showed excellent catalytic activity (Fig. 13 ). Computational studies revealed that the CoN3–C active sites of as synthesized SAC, exhibit the unique ability to concurrently activate both TMBQ and H2 molecules. Consequently, this leads to significantly lower reaction barriers compared to those observed on the Co(111) surface, owing to the reasonable adsorption energies exhibited by the substrates. 2.1.3 Hydrogenation of quinoline The selective hydrogenation of N-heterocyclic compounds, such as quinoline and its derivatives, is a crucial transformation reaction because of their broad applications in the fine chemical and pharmaceutical industries. For this transformation, various attempts have been made using noble metals as catalysts owing to their ability to carry out homolytic cleavage of H2 i.e. H- spillover, whereas in SACs, due to the absence of metal-metal bonds, hydrogen must undergo heterolytic dissociation, which has a higher activation barrier compared to the homolytic dissociation pathway. This higher barrier consequently limits the hydrogenation activity of SACs. In this regard, Shen et al. [73] utilized the combination of Ir SACs with Ir NPs supported over mesoporous carbon (CMK) i.e. Ir1+NPs/CMK catalyst for hydrogenation of quinoline (Fig. 14 ). They have confirmed with computational and experimental studies that Ir₁ single sites activate quinoline, whereas Ir nanoparticles enhance hydrogen dissociation. This generated H atoms from Ir NPs migrate to quinoline through Ir SACs by which hydrogenation takes place. Ir1+NPs/CMK catalyst showed 7800 h−1 TOF which is 20,000 times higher than that of Ir1/CMK and IrNPs/CMK catalysts. 2.2 Hydrogen production The production of green hydrogen (H2) from renewable energy sources is the need of an hour for carbon neutralization. However, its transportation and future applicability hindered due to its low bulk density. Hence, its storage depends on high-density mediums like methane, methanol and ammonia, and among them ammonia has large storage capacity. Recently, Li et al. [17]. reported a catalytic production of hydrogen from ammonia by utilizing Ni single sites on CeO2 nanosheets under thermal and solar heating excitation conditions (Fig. 15A ). The catalyst demonstrated superior H2 yield compared to the published one including noble metals, with a speed of ammonia splitting of 3.544 mmolg−1min−1 at a comparatively low reaction temperature of 300 °C. Additionally, the Bader charge study revealed the electronegative difference between Ni of Ni/CeO2 SAC and Ni of Ni (111) which further confirmed that NNi was coordinated by ionic in SA Ni/CeO2 (111) and covalent bonding in Ni (111). The dissociation of NNi in SA Ni/CeO2 (111) was more accessible than that of NNi in Ni (111), as the bond energy of ionic NNi was lower than that of covalent NNi. These findings showed that NH3 preferentially dehydrogenates on SA Ni/CeO2 (111) in comparison to Ni (111) because of the covalent to ionic change in NNi bonding. Therefore, DFT studies confirmed that to improve the NH3 splitting activity, Ni single atoms can convert the covalent binding of Ni-N to an ionic bond. Furthermore, Li et al. [74]. derived Co-N-C SAC from MOF and utilized it for H2 production via selective dehydrogenation of formic acid and compared the activity with Co nanoparticles. Various characterization techniques confirmed that owing to the formation of CoIINx centers as active sites in Co-C-N SACs, they showed superior catalytic activity with better acid resistance and enhanced long-term stability for selective dehydrogenation of HCOOH (Fig. 15B).- 2.3 Oxidation reactions 2.3.1 Methane oxidation Lee et al. [75]. reported the high metal loaded i.e., 17.7 wt% of Cu single site catalyst (CuNC-600) with N and C doping with Cu(I)N3 active centers for the partial oxidation of methane to methanol. The catalyst was synthesized via simple pyrolysis of Cu-benzimidazole coordination polymer which generates CuNx active centers without any use of N doping source. As synthesized catalyst showed excellent mass activity of 6.1 mmol g−1 at 50 °C temperature and was superior than previously reported noble metal and non-noble metal catalysts with ∼90% selectivity toward C1 liquid product using H2O2 as an oxidant. Based on experiments, the hydroxyl radical is primarily responsible for methane activation, whereas the superoxide radical controls the entire chemical pathways of CH3OH and CH3OOH synthesis (Fig. 16 ). 2.3.2 Partial oxidation of benzene Furthermore, Liu et al. [76]. synthesized Cu-based SAC with B, N co-coordination over carbon nanosheets via pyrolysis of pre-coordinated Cu precursor. The synthesized catalyst named Cu1/B–N with the Cu–N2B1 atomic interface exhibited excellent catalytic activity of 75% conversion for benzene oxidation to phenol at 60 ℃ temperature with H2O2 as an oxidant (Fig. 17A ). When compared with Cu1/N–C, Cu NPs/N–C, and N–C catalysts, Cu1/B–N SACs showed superior catalytic activity. Computational studies revealed that the electronic structure of Cu SACs induced by boron atoms with coordination of Cu–N2B1 atomic interface plays a key role in intermediate adsorption. Similarly, Zhang et al. [77]. synthesized Cu-N1O2 SA/CN catalyst via water molecule-mediated pre-assembly-pyrolysis method where Cu1-N1O2 coordinated on N/C material. The synthesized catalyst showed 83.7% conversion with 98.1% selectivity towards phenol product with a low amount of H2O2/benzene molar ratio i.e., 2:1 at 60 ℃ temperature (Fig. 17B). Cu-N1O2 SA/CN catalyst exhibited 435 h−1 TOF which is surprisingly higher than that of Cu1-N2, Cu1-N3, and Cu nanoparticles i.e., 190, 90, and 58 h−1 respectively. Additionally, Jin et al. [78]. also reported Cu SACs with high density (0.1–2.4 atoms/nm2) for catalytic conversion of benzene partial oxidation with high efficiency (Fig. 17C). DFT studies revealed that the electronic structures of Cu single atoms were changed by interactions between nearby single-atom moieties in ultra-high-density Cu SAC and consequently, greater •OH adsorption, which suppresses the side reaction of O2 production and increases the rate of the benzene hydroxylation reaction. Mainly, because of the ultra-high density of Cu single atom (2.4-Cu1/NOC) of 2.4 atoms/nm2 (21.3 wt%), the maximum mass-specific activity and H2O2 utilization efficiency occurred. Furthermore, Liu et al. [79] synthesized oxygen-coordinated metal SACs with high metal loadings of Fe, Co, Ni, and Mn metals. They applied new synthetic approach to prepare SACs directly from metal NPs supported on graphene oxide in an inert atmosphere at 750 ℃ for 2 h. Among these SACs, Fe/C was further utilized for the selective oxidation of benzene to phenol using hydrogen peroxide as an oxidizing agent and CH3CN as a solvent. The SAC showed ∼85% conversion with 99% selectivity in 8 h of reaction whereas commercially available FePO4 and FePO4/GO showed only 16 and 1.4% conversion respectively. The results confirmed the superior catalytic activity of SACs over traditional NPs. 2.3.3 Peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation for contaminants degradation The degradation of antibiotics, endocrine disruptors, and pesticides from contaminated water is getting great attention worldwide owing to their non-biodegradability and harmful impact on human health (Fig. 18 ). In this regard, PMS has been recently utilized as an oxidant in the field of environmental remediation. PMS activation to singlet oxygen 1O2 via SACs is a highly efficient and selective approach due to their coordinated structure modulation. Recently, Wang et al. [80]. reported Co SAC (Co−N3O1) with N and O coordination on oxygen-doped carbon nitride (TCN) via pyrolysis of hydrogen-bonded cyanuric acid melamine–cobalt acetate precursor which showed excellent mass activity of 7.61×105 min−1 mol−1 with high selectivity. Experimental and DFT studies revealed that Co−N3O1 moiety on TCN has a dual N and O coordination environment which promotes the PMS adsorption and as a result decreases in energy barriers observed and leads to the formation of 1O2 (Fig. 19 ). As synthesized catalyst was further attached with poly(vinylidene fluoride) microfiltration membrane and then employed for an antibiotic wastewater treatment which showed 97.5% ciprofloxacin rejection over 10 h. Similarly, Qi et al. [81]. reported a Co-N/C catalyst where N is coordinated with Co single atom using lignin as carbon source for naproxen (NPX) degradation. They observed that the rate of the reaction is dependent on Co content in SACs. Co-N/C SAC with 2.45 wt% of Co loading, showed a remarkably high TOF of 4.82 min−1 for NPX degradation (Fig. 20 ). Moreover, Liang et al. [82]. optimized and reported Co SAC (Co-Nx) with varying different coordination numbers (x = 2, 3, 4) with nitrogen of Co for PMS activation (Fig. 21 ). Based on coordination numbers (x = 2, 3, 4), the catalysts are named as Co-N2, Co-N3, Co-N4 respectively. The catalytic activity pattern for PMS activation was observed among all three catalysts as: Co-N2> Co-N3> Co-N4. Computational and experimental studies revealed that as coordination numbers decreases, the electron density of Co single atom in Co-Nx increases which leads the Fenton-like performance of Co-Nx catalysts. Co-pyridinic NC motifs act as active centers for PMS activation and singlet oxygen generation and are utilized for the degradation of BPA and domestic wastewater treatment (Fig. 22 ). Moreover, Zhang et al. [83]. synthesized Fe1/CN SACs supported on graphitic carbon nitride with 11.2 wt% loading of Fe. Synthesized SAC have highly uniform Fe-N4 active sites which exhibited 100% singlet oxygen from PMS and showed high efficiency for p-chlorophenol degradation. Computational studies confirmed that Fe1/CN SACs interact with the terminal oxygen of PMS followed by generating SO5 .− which produces singlet oxygen with 100% selectivity, unlike Co and Ni SACs. Similarly, Yang et al. [84]. synthesized FeSA-N-C and FeSA-N/C from Fe-doped ZIF-8 and FePcZIF-8 with Fe-Nx active sites which showed superior catalytic activity for PMS activation for bisphenol A (BPA) oxidation. For PMS activation and electrochemical degradation of BPA, the nonradical pathway was dominating in the case of PMS+FeSA-N/C-20 via electron transfer rather than a singlet oxygenation process or a high-valent iron. A "donor-acceptor complex" mechanism allowed the BPA to be adsorbed onto the Fe-Nx site, forming a nonradical PMS* intermediate. The PMS + FeSA-N/C-20 system demonstrated broad pH adaptation and strong resistance to inorganic anions by utilizing this mechanism. Similarly, Qian et al. [85]. reported Fe SAC (FeSA-N-CNT) with FeN4 coordination with carbon nanotube (CNT) for selective degradation of organic contaminants and pollutants. FeSA-N-CNT catalyst generates reactive iron species (RFeS) in the presence of PMS. The rapid generation of RFeS for the selective and efficient degradation of pollutants over a wide pH range is still challenging. The catalytic system showed excellent reactivity and selectivity for oxidizing organic pollutants over a wide range of pH i.e., 3–9. Through DFT calculations, it was estimated that for PMS activation, CNT plays an important role by enhancing the activity of FeN4 O intermediate and as a result increasing the degradation of BPA. This SAC showed RFeS generation over a broad pH range which increases its practical applicability. Furthermore, Li et al. [86]. synthesized Co SAC on N-doped graphene (SACo@NG) with 4.1 wt% Co content for PMS activation for efficient and selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BzOH) to benzaldehyde with 90% conversion within 180 min under mild conditions. Various experiments have been performed to analyse the radical and non-radical oxidation pathways where few assumptions were made and investigated by control experiments (Fig. 23 ). They have observed both radical and non-radical processes but the adsorption of BzOH/PMS on the surface of SACo@NG facilitates the non-radical oxidation, which is the primary process, and electron transfers through the carbon matrix (Fig. 24 ). Moreover, Song et al. [87]. reported a palladium-free Wacker oxidation of olefin to ketone using Cu SAC with 14% copper loading under mild reaction conditions (Fig. 25 ). 4-vinyl anisole was opted as a model substrate. Isotope labeling experiments revealed a hydrogen transformation during the reaction process while using the N-methyl hydroxylamine hydrochloride as the oxygen source. They also further explored for Kuchreov reaction using terminal alkyne. 2.4 Coupling reactions In synthetic chemistry, the construction of CC and CN bonds are the key reactions to synthesize pharmaceutical drugs and chemicals [88]. To increase the selectivity for the desired product, catalysts are required in these reactions. However, the use of noble metal catalysts like Pd, Pt, etc. increases the selectivity but also the process cost [89]. To deal with this issue, SAC of non-noble metal catalysts are great choice without compromising the selectivity. In this regard, Li et al. [90]. synthesized Co SACs by utilizing commercially available Co2O3 over nitrogen-doped carbon support and employed for CC coupling of benzyl alcohol and 1-phenyl ethanol with 1 atm pressure of O2 at 80 °C. The catalyst showed high catalytic activity and TOF of 2307 h−1 with 95% yield for the chalcone product and tolerance for broad functional substrates. Computational studies revealed that the catalytic activity and mechanism greatly affected by the coordination environment and electronic metal-support interaction. Similarly, Cu supported on N-doped graphene with Cu-N4 moieties was synthesized by Zhang et al. [91]. and utilized for CN coupling of aryl iodides and alkylamines. Cu SACs/NG catalyst showed activity for large substrate scope with excellent recyclability with >91% yield and with high TON of 3800. Synthesized SAC showed a lower energy barrier and high catalytic activity than Cu nanoparticles owing to the presence of large active sites. The catalytic cycle involves both oxidative addition and reductive elimination as shown in Fig. 26 . Furthermore, recently Sun et al. [92]. synthesized a bifunctional CoSA-N/NC catalyst for the formation of ethane-1,2-diamines via CC and CN coupling of nitroarenes and HCHO. The catalyst showed good recyclability and reusability with good substrate compatibility. Control experiments revealed that the Co-N4 of Co SAC acts as active sites for reduction reaction and for insitu trapping of hydroxylamine, HCHO was activated by N-doped carbon support so that nitrones can be generated in weak alkaline medium. After this, 1,3-cycloaddition of nitrones and imines took place to yield the product via the hydrodeoxygenation of cycloadducts (Fig. 27 ). 2.5 Miscellaneous 2.5.1 Hydrophosphinylation of alkenes Organophosphorus compounds are a significant class of fine and industrial chemicals due to their applications as ligands in various metal-catalyzed processes, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, extractants, flame-retardants, etc. [93]. For hydrophosphinylation of alkenes to yield alkyl phosphorus compounds, the efficiency was compromised with homogeneous catalysis. Hence, recently, Xu et al. [94]. synthesized atomically dispersed Cu on MgO nanosheets with doping of Al3+ with 6.3 wt% loading of copper and employed for the free-radical hydrophosphinylation of alkenes (Fig. 28 ). Al3+ dopants of Cu1/MgO(Al) catalyst help to create Mg2+ vacancies to stabilize the Cu atom. For comparison, Cu nanoparticles were also synthesized without doping of the Al3+ dopant named Cu/MgO. Cu1/MgO(Al) single atom catalyst showed 99% selectivity for hydrophosphinylation reaction towards anti-Markovnikov product with 1272 h−1 TOF which was 6 times higher than that of Cu/MgO. Experimental and DFT calculations revealed that due to the presence of Cu single atom, the phosphinoyl radical generation was accelerated. 2.5.2 Removal of indoor formaldehyde Gaseous formaldehyde (HCHO) emissions are a health hazard that can be gradually released by indoor building and decorative materials. However, significant efforts have been made by scientific community to eradicate indoor HCHO such as photocatalysis, oxidation reaction, and physical adsorption. In this regard, recently Tang et al. [95]. utilized Co SACs with N-doped carbon for the first time for catalytic removal of HCHO. The synthesized catalyst showed remarkable performance for ∼1 ppm formaldehyde at room temperature. DFT studies revealed that formaldehyde reacts with adsorbed oxygen molecules through Co single atom with following the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) pathway to produce CO2 and water (HCHO → HCOO* → CO2). 3 Conclusion and outlook In recent years, considerable development has been done in the field of organic synthesis for chemoselective hydrogenation, oxidation, and degradation reactions. Various promising pathways have been developed and employed to make the approach environmentally benign, affordable, sustainable, and cost-effective. Some reactions and their used catalysts need to be improved to make them efficient and selective. Also, several efforts have been accomplished to replace the precious metal catalysts without compromising selectivity and activity. In this review, we have thoroughly discussed various organic transformations like, chemoselective hydrogenation, oxidation, hydrogen production, CC and CN coupling, hydrophosphinylation, and removal of indoor HCHO using 3d metal-based single-atom catalysts with high selectivity and activity. 3d metal-based SACs showed remarkable catalytic activity, selectivity, and recyclability for large substrate scope at mild reaction conditions. Usually, dehalogenation and uncontrolled reduction occurs during hydrogenation under high H2 pressure which reduces the selectivity of the desired product and makes the overall process expensive. In this regard, 3d transition metals like Co, Cu, Ni, and Fe showed excellent catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes with selectivity at low reaction temperature and pressure. These methodologies can be applicable in organic synthetic bulk-scale applications. Furthermore, SACs showed versatility for other activator-based reactions like antibiotic or medicinal wastewater treatment via peroxymonosulfate activation to singlet oxygen. We have also discussed the mechanistic pathway for these reactions via SACs. Based on the assessment, the below conclusive points are made which can be helpful for further improvement: 1) The oxygen vacancies, coordination number, chemical environment, and electronic structure greatly affected the SAC activity which can be tuned by changing the precursors, reaction parameters etc. during the synthesis of SAC. SACs showed outstanding catalytic performance with high selectivity, easy recyclability, and low process cost. However, the synthesis and characterization of SACs is still challenging as single atoms have high surface free energy and it tend to agglomerate in the form of bulk and nanoparticles. 2) To characterize these materials advanced technologies like aberration-corrected scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (AC-STEM), Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS), Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS), and Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy (EELS) etc. to confirm the coordination environment, electronic structure, doping of the atom on support. The continuous development and variety of high-resolution characterization techniques are essential for promoting the steady growth of single-atom catalysts (SACs). 3) The modification and tuning of existing metal catalysts is required to improve the catalytic activity. The tuning of existing metal catalysts can be done by varying the synthesis parameters like temperature, synthesis time, and different metal-ligand combinations. The active metal atom loading as well as support material plays an important role in tuning the catalytic activity which can be analyzed by varying these parameters. 4) Doping of various metals like N, C, S, and B can anchor the sites in the SACs and enhance the selectivity and activity [96,97]. This also helps to tune the coordination environment around the center metal and strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) can enhance the catalytic activity [33,98,99]. 5) Moreover, it has been observed that bimetallic systems have higher catalytic activity than monometallic catalytic systems owing to the synergistic effect between the existing metals [21,100,101]. Keeping this in mind, dual single-metal atom catalysts (DSACs) should be explored and synthesized for various transformation reactions and CO2 hydrogenation reactions [102]. 6) Developing new synthetic approaches to prepare a stable coordination environment for single atoms on supports needs to be explored to prevent the migration and agglomeration of metal atoms during preparation and reaction processes [103]. Optimistically, developing new synthetic processes and metal-ligand combinations of 3d transition metal-based SACs will replace the traditionally utilized noble metal catalysts in industries and will help to make the process economic. coredata.dc:description: Single-atom catalysts (SACs) show potential applications for various organic transformation reactions due to their easy recyclability, high exposure to active sites, and unique electronic structures. Owing to highly exposed active sites, SACs exhibit superior catalytic activity and chemoselectivity compared to metal nanoparticles. This mini-review comprehensively outlines the recent progress in chemoselective hydrogenation, dehydrogenation, CC and CN cross-coupling reactions, peroxymonosulfate activation, production of hydrogen and ammonia by employing 3d transition metals such as Co, Cu, Fe, Ni-based SACs. These reactions are key steps in organic synthetic chemistry and pharmaceutical industries, and utilizing earth-abundant 3d-metal SACs without compromising the selectivity and activity made these reactions cost-effective, sustainable, and industrially applicable. We also illustrate the mechanistic pathways for these reactions and highlight the key challenges and future opportunities to improve the existing SACs. Moreover, we believe that this review may help to address the existing issues of chemoselectivity in organic synthesis as well as promote the development of SACs.
